intro: Eupatorium trianae, commonly known as the Cuban boneset, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of South America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small umbels. The plant typically grows in wetlands and marshy areas, thriving in humid, tropical climates. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and white or pale blue. Eupatorium trianae is known for its aromatic properties and has been used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antiseptic effects.
